{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3525271,"name":"","username":"AvocadoPeel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avocadopeel/{size}/232401_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T20:06:27.157Z","cooked":"

Why does the DynamicMotionMagic request require the device to be on a canivore? Does the extra data really require Can FD?

@CTRE

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-12T20:06:27.157Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":182,"readers_count":181,"score":76.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":491410,"topic_slug":"ctre-dynamicmotionmagic","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/groups/ctre","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61239,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/ctre-dynamicmotionmagic/491410/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3525371,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T21:35:32.596Z","cooked":"

Yes, the extra data requires CAN FD. CAN 2.0 only supports 8 bytes of data, which is not enough space to store position, cruise velocity, acceleration, jerk, arbitrary feedforward, and the 7 other parameters.

To put into perspective how much 8 bytes can store, that is equivalent to any one of the following:

  • one double
  • two floats or ints
  • four shorts
  • eight ASCII characters

Needless to say, it’s not a lot of space. Dynamic Motion Magic® has two more floating-point parameters than even PositionVoltage, which already pushes the limits of CAN 2.0. On the other hand, CAN FD supports data payloads of up to 64 bytes, which is more than enough space for all those parameters.

Wow that really puts it into perspective. I wonder how many other cool bits of information and thought were put into designing the software ecosystem behind Phoenix API. I am sure I and many others would love to read a blog post about it!

the docs specify a fault is thrown if the device is unlicensed, but not if the device is on an FD bus. If a DynamicMotionMagic request is given to a device not on canivore, what is the behaviou? does it fall back to regular motion magic or throw a fault?

I believe the device will be disabled, and the setControl call will return a TxFailed error because the size of the control frame is invalid on CAN 2.0.
